videos.title: Guitarmann Advanced Essentials Series Welcome
videos.description: In the http://guitarmann.com Advanced Essentials Video Series, youll learn an intricate knowledge of both music and guitar. You will learn the secret to how to create and play every single chord that exists without memorizing chord books. Learn power chords, bar chords, jazz chords, blues chords, augmented, diminished, 9 chords, 7 chords, and more. Youll not only learn these chords, but you will also see how they fit in with chord families so you can create unique progressions in your song writing. So grab your guitar and head over the guitarmnann.com!

videos.title: Guitarmann Electric Series Welcome
videos.description: In the http://guitarmann.com Electric Video Series, youll learn the most efficient way to play the electric guitar. After you are introduced to the electric, you will learn warm-up techniques, the pentatonic scales used for blues and rock soloing, the 5 major scales so you can solo all over the neck, how modes work to create unique soloing, and 5 positions of complement mini-chords to help you complement a rhythm guitar. So grab your guitar and head over to guitarmann.com

videos.title: Guitarmann Essentials Series Welcome
videos.description: In the http://guitarmann.com Essentials Video Series, youll learn what every guitar player should know without wasting time of the stuff that you dont. Youll learn how to play the most common chord families, how to use a capo all over the neck, how to transpose into any key that exists, how to read studio charts that professionals in Nashville use every day, and ultimately how to play rhythm guitar to any song in any key. So grab your guitar and head over to guitarmann.com

videos.title: Guitarmann Beginner Series Welcome
videos.description: In the http://guitarmann.com Beginner Video Series, you dont need to read music, and you dont have to have any background whatsoever in music. Youll learn step by step instructions to help you learn basic chords, chord switching, a simple strum pattern, very simple music concepts, and of course how to play through a few songs. If you have questions about anything you are learning, you can post a question on the Guitarmann Forum. So grab your guitar and head over to guitarmann.com!

videos.title: Christian Guitar Lessons | Guitarmann
videos.description: See what http://guitarmann.com is all about in this intro video. You will get a sneak peak into the Guitarmann Christian Guitar Lessons. Stephen explains about the 4 tiers of his unique teaching method: Beginner, Essentials, Electric, and Advanced Essentials. You'll also see how the site is constantly updated with weekly lessons, artist interviews, blog posts and more. Also, you'll hear about other great features such as forums where you can ask any question.

videos.title: Guitarmann Interview with Jason Roy of Building 429
videos.description: In an exclusive http://guitarmann.com interview, Jason Roy from Building 429 fields questions about song writing, guitar influences, and even the thought process of playing live. He discusses alternate tunings, electric guitars, favorite amps, favorite pedals, and acoustic guitars. Guitarmann members can login to http://guitarmann.com and watch Jason Roy teach you how to play the award-winning song, "Glory Defined."

videos.title: Guitar Anatomy (Parts of the Guitar) Guitar Lesson
videos.description: This free http://guitarmann.com video lesson shows you all of the parts of the guitar. otherwise known as the "guitar anatomy." This is part of the Guitarmann Beginner video series, which teaches you everything you need to learn how to play guitar.

videos.title: How to Restring Your Guitar (Guitarmann Beginner Video Series)
videos.description: In this free http://guitarmann.com Beginner video series guitar lesson, you'll learn step by step instructions on how to restring your guitar. You will even find out when it's time to change your guitar strings. For more beginner guitar videos, check out http://guitarmann.com for guitar lessons that cover all the bases so that you can learn how to play common chords, strum patterns, and your first few songs.

videos.title: Musical Alphabet Guitar Lesson-- from the Guitarmann Beginner Video Series
videos.description: In this free http://guitarmann Beginner video lesson, you'll learn the most foundational concept in understanding music---the musical alphabet. This simple approach to learning all 12 notes in music will be helpful later on in understanding chord structure, scales, and even forming new types of chords. Make sure you learn this well!

videos.title: I Could Sing of Your Love Forever Guitar Lesson (Guitarmann Beginner Video Series)
videos.description: In this free http://guitarmann.com Beginner video lesson, you will learn how to apply everything you have learned in the series and play through one of the most popular praise and worship songs: "I Could Sing of Your Love Forever." Soon, you'll be able to play with your praise band or just strum in your living room. For more beginner lessons, check out guitarmann.com

videos.title: G Chord Family Swtiching Guitar Lesson (Guitarmann Essentials Video Series)
videos.description: In this free http://guitarmann.com Essentials video lesson, you will learn the best way to switch from one chord to another in the key of G. These techniques will give your left hand the practice it needs to quickly switch from one chord to another when your playing your favorite worship song or just jamming with others.

videos.title: Your Love Oh Lord (Third Day) Guitar Lesson (Guitarmann Essentials Video Series)
videos.description: In this free http://guitarmann.com lesson, you will learn how to play a very popular praise and worship song: "Your Love oh Lord." This song, made famous by the band, Third Day, is a great way to apply many chords in the G chord family along with the common 4/4 strum pattern. Once you learn this great worship song, you will be able to join a praise team in leading worship, or just play with friends. Learn more about chord families and how to play every song in every key at guitarmann.com!

videos.title: E Chord Family Chords Guitar Lesson (Guitarmann Essentials Video Series)
videos.description: In this free http://guitarmann.com Essentials video lesson, you will learn the most common chords used in the key of E. Once you learn all of the chords in a chord family, you will be able to play 90% of songs in that key. To learn more about chords families and to ultimately play in every key that exists, visit guitarmann.com today.

videos.title: Chromatic Scale (Warm up scale) Guitar Lesson (Guitarmann Electric Video Series)
videos.description: In this free http://guitarmann.com Electric Series video lesson, you will learn one of the best finger warm up exercises for playing solos on the electric guitar. When you master this scale, you will be ready to conquer scales that you can use in soloing. This scale will strengthen your fingers and provide the flexibility you need to shred.

videos.title: Speed Drills Guitar Lesson (Guitarmann Electric Video Series)
videos.description: In this free http://guitarmann.com Electric Series video lesson, you will learn some of the best techniques to help build your finger speed so that you can solo faster than ever. Finger speed comes from finger coordination with the scale through muscle memory as well as finger strength and dexterity. This video will shows you ways to improve all of the above. To learn more about soloing all over the neck, visit http://guitarmann.com today.

videos.title: Introduction to Complement Chords Guitar Lesson (Guitarmann Electric Video Series)
videos.description: In this http://guitarmann.com Electric Series video lesson, you will learn about complement chords are used to tastefully complement an rhythm guitar without over-powering it. Complement chords are 3 string chords found in different positions along the fret board. They are used often especially in praise and worship music  to create signature licks.

videos.title: Bar Chord Quiz Guitar Lesson (Guitarmann Advanced Essentials Video Series)
videos.description: This free http://guitarmann.com Advanced Essentials video lesson will quiz you on your bar chords. Do you think you know all of your bar chords in both the 6th and 5th string positions? See if you can answer all of the questions. Bar chords are the basis for learning more difficult jazz and blues chords and ultimately creating every chord that exists on guitar. To learn more about advanced music principles and how they relate to guitar, visit http://guitarmann.com today!

videos.title: Chords Outside of the Chord Family Guitar Lesson (Guitarmann Advanced Essentials Video Series)
videos.description: In this free http://guitarmann.com Advanced Essentials video series, you will learn about the unique chords that can be mixed into the normal chords of a chord family to provide an interesting twist in song writing. These chords provide a break from the norm and have specific sounds. Maybe you want an oldies chord sound. Perhaps you want a Spanish sounding chord mixed in. To learn more about these chords and to learn how to create every chord that exists, visit http://guitarmann.com today!

videos.title: Did Chris Tomlin and I Write the Same Song?
videos.description:
As my wife was humming "Chosen Generation" in the car, I asked why she was humming my song "Live for You," which she hadn't heard in over a year. I realized that the two songs were very similar: same key, very similar note structure, and even similar words!

I wrote and recorded "Live for You" in March 2009. For those who think this is a hoax, I have proof that I wrote this song. I have a dated email with this song attached, and there are at least 3 people who have the demo CD I gave them in March 09 with this song on it, even though I didn't copyright it at the time. 

Even though "Chosen Generation" was recorded January 2010, I really don't think that somehow my song was an inspiration for "Chosen Generation." The odds of that are beyond slim, and I don't think Chris Tomlin would steal somebody's song. I think it's just a coincidence and a cool one at that. I'm actually inspired to write and record a little more and even someday release a CD. 

Stephen Mann
http://guitarmann.com

videos.title: King of Kings Cover (Hillsong Worship)
videos.description:
Free charts: https://guitarmann.com/articles/king-kings-chord-chart This is an awesome Hillsong worship song that is very poetic and depicts the story of Jesus. 
Musically, many of the chords share a measure; however, because the song is fairly slow, it's not too hard to switch between chords. One interesting twist in the chords is that the 1/3 chord is replaced with a 6m chord on the 3rd verse. 
Because the song repeats the verse and chord structure quite a bit, this substitution chords helps keep the verse interesting and not too redundant. Also, there are a few chords that have only 2 beats, and the time technically switches to 2/4 time just for those beats. 
Hope you enjoy and happy strumming!

videos.title: God So Loved Guitar Tutorial | We the Kingdom | Acoustic
videos.description:
Free charts here: https://guitarmann.com/articles/god-so-loved-chord-chart

7:01 Full Play Along

"God So Loved" by We the Kingdom is a really fun song that's great for Easter or for any service opening if you like to start with energy. Lyrically, it's built around John 3:16 and it's pretty straight forward. Playing it is easy as well, and there aren't any curve balls. 

I'm playing this song in the key of G, but you can simply capo 3 to shift it into the original key of Bb like the original recording.

videos.title: God So Loved | Nashville Numbers Play Along
videos.description:
Free Charts: https://guitarmann.com/articles/god-so-loved-chord-chart

If you haven't tried Nashville Numbers, now is a good time to start! In the previous tutorial, you learned how to play this song: https://youtu.be/QpfJ4atO2n8 

After you feel comfortable with playing through the song, try using this video and playing along with Nashville Numbers. Notice that a 1 chord represents a G chord. A 4 chord represents a C chord, and a 5 chord represents a D chord. For more on Nashville Numbers, check out the Intermediate Guitar Course on my site: https://guitarmann.com/categories/guitar

videos.title: Graves Into Gardens Guitar Tutorial | Elevation Worship
videos.description:
Free Charts: https://guitarmann.com/articles/graves-into-gardens-chord-chart
In this lesson, you'll learn how to play the rhythm acoustic guitar part of Graves into Gardens by Elevation Worship. There are two ways to play the intro part of G suspended into a G open chord. This change is what makes the song recognizable. 
You can skip ahead to the full play-along at 5:25.

"Holy Forever" is a new Chris Tomlin worship song that was co-written by Phil Wickham, Brian Johnson, Jason Ingram, and Jenn Johnson. It's from the "Always" album, released by Sparrow Records in September 2022.

Musically, the song is in 4/4 time and is a medium pace. It's in the key of C# or Db; so, it's best to play it on guitar with either capo 1 in C or capo 6 in G. Of course, you can adjust you capo position in case you need a higher or lower key that fits either a male or female vocal better.

This acoustic guitar lesson will walk you through how to play in each position and includes a full play-along section at the end of the tutorial.

The chord structure is simple; however, there are several quick chord changes that last for only one beat.

The easiest way to strum this on guitar, is to play down-strums that follow the rhythm of "1 and 2 and 3 and 4 and," where each gets a down strum. This will help you count out exactly when to play each chord.

Alternatively, you can play the first part of the normal 4/4 strum pattern that you learned in the Beginner Course, and just substitute the last DUDU with one down strum. 

That last down strum will represent the passing chord that lasts for only one beat. 

If a chord doesn't share any other chords with it in the measure (there is no box), then you can use a full strum pattern for that particular chord.  

The song is a great anthem to add to any worship set on Sunday or otherwise! It's also a great song to play on guitar in either capo position.

videos.description:
Download the free worship charts: https://guitarmann.com/articles/battle-belongs-lesson-and-chords
Time Stamps:
00:00 Intro

Start any Guitarmann course for $1: https://guitarmann.com/categories/guitar

"Battle Belongs" is a Phil Wickham worship song that was co-written by Brian Johnson, and is from the album "Hymn of Heaven" released in 2021.

Musically, the song is in 4/4 time and is upbeat. It's in the key of Db (or C#); so, it's best to play it on guitar with either capo 1 in C or capo 6 in G. Of course, you can adjust you capo position in case you need a higher or lower key that fits either a male or female vocal better.

For instance, the play-along video above is in the key of B, which may be a little more comfortable for a male vocal. To play in the key of B, use a capo on the 4th fret, using the G chord family. Or you can also capo on the 2nd fret and use the A chord family.

For the strum pattern, I'll cover 3 different ways to play it based on your skill level. The first way is a simplified strum that will work throughout the song.

The intermediate way to play it will add in a few extra strums to make it sound full and will get your right hand into a simple groove that will help you keep a consistent rhythm throughout the song.

Finally, there is a more advanced strum pattern that will add in some percussive sounds so that it sounds like there is a drum playing along with you. 

You'll also learn how to add in the intro signature lick as you strum. This is a great worship song to learn on guitar, so spend some time with the tutorial to learn the different ways to play it.

My Commentary on the Lyrics of this Song: 

"When all I see is the battle
You see my victory
When all I see is the mountain
You see a mountain moved"

"And as I walk through the shadow
Your love surrounds me
There’s nothing to fear now
For I am safe with You"

This song starts with a the different perspectives of man and God, as it seen in Psalm 23 "though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil." 

There is a constant battle of fear based on man's perspective; however, the first verse also illustrates that from God's perspective, there is, in fact, nothing to fear!

"So when I fight
I’ll fight on my knees
With my hands lifted high
Oh God the battle Belongs to You"

"And every fear I lay at Your feet
I’ll sing through the night
Oh God the battle belongs to You"

The chorus demonstrates that prayer is the best way to face fear and have our minds renewed (Romans 12), which, in turn, renews our perspective. 

The pinnacle of the song, lyrically, is that the act of submitting the battle is in fact the whole point. Fighting the battle is not the point. The fear is only laid to rest upon its submission.   

There is also an element of "singing" that accompanies submission. Singing and praising God is not possible without that spirit. Worshipping God implies a surrender.   

"And if You are for me
Who can be against me
For Jesus there’s nothing
Impossible for You"

"When all I see are the ashes
You see the beauty
When all I see is a cross
God You see the empty tomb"

The next set of verses reinforces the idea of the first verse and the chorus, but with more bold proclamations found in Romans 8:31 "And if our God is for us, who can be against us."

The verses also move into a Gospel centered message, basing this perspective on the work of the cross and resurrection. 

Let's take a look at the lyrics of the bridge:  

"Almighty Fortress
You go before us
Nothing can stand against The power of our God"

"You shine in the shadow
You win every battle
Nothing can stand against The power of our God"

The proclamations get even bolder at this point in the song, and are the natural progression of a state of fear to a state of confidence in Christ. The perspective shifts from man looking at himself in fear, to looking solely to God in confidence. 

The chorus repeats with another exclamation point that the battle belongs to God. This is a great worship song that is upbeat and if a great one to learn on guitar!

videos.description:

"Great Things" is a Phil Wickham worship song that was co-written by Jonas Myrin and is from the album "Living Hope" released in 2018.

Musically, the song is in 4/4 time and is pretty upbeat. It's in the key of B; so, it's best to play it on acoustic guitar with a capo on the 4th fret in G. Of course, you can adjust you capo position in case you need a higher or lower key that fits either a male or female vocal better.

For instance, the play-along video above is in the key of G, which may be a little more comfortable for a male vocal. 

Because the song is 102 beats per minute, it's on the faster side and requires a pretty quick strum pattern. I'll cover a few different ways to play it in the guitar tutorial above.

There are also a few different ways to play it, depending on the part of the song. The bridge, for instance, starts down and then ramps up. Once you know the different strum patterns for the different parts of the song, you'll be able to play right along. 

You'll also learn how to play the intro lick in case you are interested. This is a simple 2 string lick for electric; however, you can also play it on acoustic. 

Now, let's take a look at the lyrics of Great Things:

Come let us worship our King
Come let us bow at His feet
He has done great things

See what our Savior has done
See how His love overcomes
He has done great things

Lyrically, this song begins with a simple call to worship. Keep this in mind, as it's a great song as an opener in a worship set. 

The focus is on what God has done for us; specifically, His love for as our our Savior. This verse implies that the work of God is salvation, itself, and that work is the "great thing" that He has done on our behalf.

There is also an implication that the work He has done is not improving our circumstances, or giving us what we think we want. We're praising Him, rather, for His outworking of salvation, by nature of Him being our Savior.

Let's look at the chorus:

Oh hero of Heaven
You conquered the grave
You free every captive
And break every chain
Oh God You have done great things

The chorus spells out the heart of the Gospel; Christ was crucified, but through the resurrection, defeated the death and the grave. Through that work, captives can be free, and the chains of sin and death can be broken.   

We dance in Your freedom
Awake and alive
Oh Jesus our Savior
Your name lifted high
Oh God You have done great things

The second part of the chorus describes our reaction to being saved. We're now awake and alive, having been dead in our trespasses (Ephesians 2:1). Once again, the focus of the response is to the work of Christ and His name worshipped.  

You've been faithful through every storm
You'll be faithful forevermore
You have done great things

And I know You will do it again
For Your promise is Yes and amen
You will do great things

This verse describes the faithfulness of God (1 Corinthians 1:9) as another great thing that He has done. 

2 Corinthians 1:20 says that all of the promises of God are "yes and amen" through Christ. When these promises are fulfilled, it points to the faithfulness of God.

After the chorus repeats, the song moves into the bridge.

Hallelujah God above it all
Hallelujah God unshakable
Hallelujah You have done great things
You've done great things

The bridge is another response to the work God has done and affirms God's nature as unwavering. From here, the song moves back into the chorus to end.

Enjoy! And feel free to reach out with any questions or comments.

videos.title: Son of Suffering Guitar Tutorial and Play Along | Matt Redman | Bethel | Worship Initiative
videos.description:
Chart Download: https://guitarmann.com/articles/son-suffering-lesson-and-chords
TimeStamps:

Today's guitar lesson is for "Son of Suffering," a song performed by Matt Redman, Bethel Music, the Worship Initiative and others. There are both light versions and full band versions of this song.

Musically, the song is in 4/4 time and you can play this in key of B, C, or Db, depending on the version you want to play. So, it's best to play it on guitar with a capo on the 4th, 5th, or 6th fret in G. Of course, you can adjust you capo position in case you need a higher or lower key that fits either a male or female vocal better.

The guitar lesson and play along above is in the key of B. 

Most any strum pattern in 4/4 should work with this song, however, I'll cover a unique strum pattern that will work especially well for the bridge of this song.

I'll also cover a finger picking patter that works with this song that can translate to flat picking as well. This is a great chance to stretch yourself into new areas if you want a challenge 

Finally, there is a signature lick in the chorus, that I'll show you how to play. As you progress through the lesson, you'll find easy ways to play it at first, and then more challenging ways to play it as we go.

Now, let's take a look at the lyrics of Son of Suffering:

Oh the perfect Son of God
In all His innocence
Walking in the dirt
With You and me

He knows what living is
He's acquainted with our grief
A Man of sorrows Son of suffering

Lyrically, this song begins with talking about who Jesus is as God. He was fully innocent and chose to enter in to the world, according to Philippians 2:6. 

However the cornerstone verse of this song is Isaiah 53:3: "He was despised, and rejected of men; a man of sorrows, and acquainted with grief."

In His human experience, He also relates to our temptations and grief that we experience.

Let's look at the chorus:

Oh blood and tears
How can it be
There's a God who weeps
There's a God who bleeds

Oh praise the One
Who would reach for me
Hallelujah to the Son of suffering

The chorus further explains God's relational characteristics expressed through weeping (John 11:35), and through bleeding. The chorus also turns to a responsive "Hallelujah" in praise.   

Some imagine You
Are distant and removed
But You chased us down
In merciful pursuit

To the sinner You were grace
And the broken You embraced
And in the end
The proof is in Your wounds
Yes, in the end
The proof is in Your wounds

The second verse turns back to man to address the common view of God, in that He is removed or too distant to care about our daily lives. However, Christ's demonstration of love on the cross also demonstrated His relational care for His sheep.

One verse that shows this is John 15:13, that "Greater love has no man than this, that a man lay down his life for his friends." We are considered friends.  

Now, let's take a look at the Bridge lyrics:

Your cross my freedom
Your stripes my healing
All praise King Jesus
Glory to God in Heaven

Your blood still speaking
Your love still reaching
All praise King Jesus
Glory to God forever

The bridge highlights some parallels between the suffering of Jesus and the result for the believer. From the cross, is freedom, and from stripes are healing. It lands with a response of worship. This is a great song to strum, or pick on guitar, and I hope you challenge yourself with the lesson above.

videos.description:
Free Chord Charts: https://guitarmann.com/articles/house-the-lord-chords-guitar-tutorial-phil-wickham
Time Stamps: 
00:00 Song Preview
01:04 Song Overview

12:54 Electric Guitar Lead Lick 
16:19 Wrap Up 

In this acoustic guitar tutorial of House of the Lord by Phil Wickham, you'll learn how to play the intro lick, the chords, and the easiest strum pattern. This song has an unusual timing; however, once you learn how to follow the chords, you'll be able to play along easily. 

You'll have a choice of different capo options, but for this lesson, we'll focus on using the G chord family using a capo on 3rd fret.

You also learn how to play the intro lick within the chords, and you'll learn how to play the electric guitar part.  

House of the Lord, also known as There's Joy in the House of the Lord, is a worship song written by Jonathan Smith, and Phil Wickham. It was released in 2021 on the label, Phil Wickham.

This song is an upbeat worship song about the joy that's in the house of the Lord, most likely referring to the gathered church. The song begins with a call to worship and moves into an expression of praise.

The first verse starts with identifying the object of the church's worship:

We worship the God who was
We worship the God who is
We worship the God who
Evermore will be

From there the chorus affirms the joy of believers, and their loud proclamation: 

There’s joy in the house of the Lord
There’s joy in the house
Of the Lord today
And we won’t be quiet
We shout out Your praise

There’s Joy in the house of the Lord
Our God is surely in this place
And we won’t be quiet
We shout out Your praise

The second verse speaks of the ways in which God is victorious, by illustrating some of the miracles of God in the Bible: 

He opened the prison doors
He parted the raging sea
Our God He holds the victory

The third as fourth verses describes more attributes of God, both in His nature as well as what he did for us as God. This set of verses ends with the core of the Gospel in Christ's work on the cross: 

We sing to the God who heals
We sing to the God who saves
We sing to the God who always
Makes a way 

'Cause He hung upon that Cross
Then He rose up from that grave
My God’s still rolling stones away
 
Next, the bridge of the song looks at the affect of the Gospel on believers and parallels the change of before and after someone is redeemed. Most of the language here is metaphorical and is referring to the spiritual state of a believer, not the literal circumstances of a believer.  

We were the beggars
Now we’re royalty
We were the prisoners
Now we’re running free
We are forgiven accepted
Redeemed by His grace
Let the house of the Lord sing praise


Finally, the song wraps up with a few more choruses to re-emphasize them main themes of the song. 

This is a great song to help begin a worship service. I hope you enjoy learning how to play it!

In this acoustic guitar tutorial of "Hymn of Heaven" by Phil Wickham, you'll learn how to play all of the chords using capo 2 in the D chord family. The strum pattern is relatively easy and focuses on down strums. You can also play this song using E chords instead. This is a fantastic worship song that worth learning.

Hymn of Heaven, also known as “There Will Be A Day,” is a worship song written by Bill Johnson, Phil Wickham, Brian Johnson, and Chris Davenport. It is the title track on the album “Hymn of Heaven,” released in 2021 on the label, Phil Wickham.

This song is a powerful ballad that reflects on the idea of longing and hoping for the future of heaven, in the midst of struggles and doubts. The lyrics speak to the day when problems will be no more and every prayer in answered.

Each verse demonstrates the reality of pain and desperation, while looking ahead. The lyrics of chorus affirm that “There will be a day when all will now before Him. There will be a day when death will be nor more. Standing face to face with He who died and rose again. Holy holy is the Lord.”

Musically, the song starts with simple piano chords, with little accompaniment. The melody is simple and easily sung. The chorus introduces a little more energy and introduces more chord changes.

There is a simple melodic piano lick that happens at the end of the chorus in order to easily identify the song and help it move back into the next verse. We'll cover this as a guitar lick.

As the song progresses, it builds musically into strong and vibrant choruses that are suited well for a full choir. Finally, the song ends with a tag to emphasize the last few words and then musically ends with a strong chord.

videos.description:

00:00 Song Preview

07:26 Strum Pattern

In this acoustic guitar tutorial of "Run to the Father" by Cody Carnes, you'll learn how to play the chord progression and strum pattern. This song uses G chord family chords with the capo on the 5th fret, which puts it in the key of C. You can also play it with C chords and no capo. This guitar lesson covers both!

Here is more info if you're new to the Nashville Number System and this style of charting: https://guitarmann.com/articles/studio-charts

Who Wrote Run to the Father?
The worship song Run to the Father was written by Cody Carnes, Matt Maher, and Ran Jackson and was released in 2020 on the label Sparrow Records. 

What is Run to the Father About?
Run to the Father has the themes of God's grace, love, mercy, trust, and surrender. Some of the scripture verses used for this song include: Matthew 11:28-30, Luke 15:17-20, and Psalm 40:11-16.  

Let's look at the lyrics of this song to see how it flows:

Verse 1

I’ve carried a burden
For too long on my own
I wasn’t created
To bear it alone

Verse 2

I hear Your invitation
To let it all go
I see it now
I’m laying it down
I know that I need You

The verses talk about recognizing the weight that we carry and the need for surrendering that to God. This realization establishes our need for Him. From here, we move into the chorus: 

Chorus

I run to the Father
I fall into grace
I’m done with the hiding
No reason to wait

My heart needs a surgeon
My soul needs a friend
So I’ll run to the Father
Again and again
And again and again

Here is the answer to our need: running to the Father. This picture reminds me of the prodigal son in the Bible. He saw his need and ran back to the father, because He knew he would be accepted. Here, we move into the next verses: 

Verse 3

You saw my condition
Had a plan from the start
Your Son for redemption
The price for my heart

Verse 4

I don’t have a context
For that kind of love
I don’t understand
I can’t comprehend
All I know is I need You

These verses speak to God's point of view and his providential plan of salvation. There is also a response of amazement and a return to our need for God, which again, sets up the chorus. The bridge happens later in the song: 

Bridge 1

My heart has been in Your sights
Long before my first breath
Running into Your arms
Is running to life from death

Bridge 2

I feel this rush deep in my chest
Your mercy is calling out
Just as I am You pull me in
I know I need You now

After the bridge, the song returns to the choruses again.
